article.description:
New Mexico center Jordan Adams posted a
season-high 22 points to help lead the Lobo women to a 77-70 victory Saturday over Texas (No. 16 ESPN/USA Today; No. 17 Associated Press).
article.headline: Adams' season-high 22 points powers Lobos
article.linkText: Adams the key as New Mexico upsets No. 16 Texas
article.story:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- New Mexico center Jordan Adams posted a
season-high 22 points to help lead the Lobo women to a 77-70 victory Saturday over Texas (No. 16 ESPN/USA Today; No. 17 Associated Press).

	   Adams also blocked a season-high five shots while going head to
head for much of the game against Texas forward Stacy Stephens.

	   Adams was ''outstanding,'' UNM coach Don Flanagan said. ''She
not only played an outstanding game on offense, but also on
defense.''

	   Stephens didn't score until 3:15 remaining the the first half.

	   She did finish with 23 points and 12 rebounds for her first
double-double of the season.

	   The Lobos (5-1), who earned the school's first at-large
invitation to the NCAA Tournament last season, hoped to gain some
national recognition with the victory over the Longhorn women (2-2).

	   The Lobo women came into the game 4-14 against Top 25 opponents overall. Last season, the Lobos' NCAA Tournament hopes were
boosted by a victory in the Pit over then-No. 8 Texas Tech.

	   ''This was a tremendous win for our program,'' Flanagan said
after the game Saturday. ''When we schedule these kinds of opponents,
it's purposeful. We want to get attention for our program.''

	   Texas, with five 3-pointers in the first half, took a 38-34 lead
to halftime, but the Lobos extended their perimeter defense and
used an 11-2 run to snatch a 51-47 lead with 11:26 left in the game
and never relinquished the lead the rest of the way.

	   With 11,484 fans cheering, New Mexico took its biggest lead of
the game at 72-62 with 1:21 left, and the Lobo women hit nine of 10
free throws down the stretch.

	   The Lobos ''gave us the perimeter shot early,'' Texas coach Jody
Conradt said. ''They adjusted in the second half and we didn't.

	   ''New Mexico is a very good team, and it would be a challenge
for any team to come in here and win,'' Conradt said.

	   Both of Texas' defeats this season have come against Mountain
West Conference opponents. Brigham Young beat Texas 79-63 in both
teams' season opener Nov. 22.
